jazyjason

Longtime L.A. Times sportswriter Mike Penner, who made headlines in 2007 when he announced he was transitioning and would be taking the name Christine Daniels, has died in L.A. Authorities suspect he committed suicide.
 
 Said Penner in his April 2007 column: Penner "Today I leave for a few weeks' vacation, and when I return, I will come back in yet another incarnation...As Christine [Daniels]...I am a transsexual sportswriter. It has taken more than 40 years, a million tears and hundreds of hours of soul-wrenching therapy for me to work up the courage to type those words. I realize many readers and colleagues and friends will be shocked to read them."
 
 Penner's gender identity made the news again last year when he announced that he would be taking back the name Mike Penner.
 
 Said Times Sports Editor Mike James: "He was one of the most talented writers I've ever worked with. He was a gentle man, a kind man. It's just a tragedy."

It has taken more than 40 years, a million tears and hundreds of hours of soul-wrenching therapy for me to work up the courage to type those words. I realize many readers and colleagues and friends will be shocked to read them."
 
 Penner's gender identity made the news again last year when he announced that he would be taking back the name Mike Penner.
 
 Said Times Sports Editor Mike James: "He was one of the most talented writers I've ever worked with. He was a gentle man, a kind man. It's just a tragedy."

 
 Links are required with articles Jason, it's a copyright policy and a forum rule. Mike Penner dies at 52; Los Angeles Times sportswriter -- latimes.com Although any suicide is a sad event, it is very telling that mike considered his decision to transition from male to female to be a life changing and life correcting choice which would undo a wrong committed against him by nature/God whom he obviously thought got it wrong by making him a male originally.
 
 Interestingly though, only one year later he took back his male name and identity followed up with this tragedy of completely abandoning life. How sad and poignant is the message that no matter how hard we try, we cannot improve on how we were originally created. And now, as we consider his journey, he now knows all too well what he had in life as a male. I sincerely mourn his loss and wish that rather than kill himself, he had groped out into the darkness of this world and sought a truth greater than what his own mind could conceive of. Because had He done that, God promises that He would have found him.

 Penner's gender identity made the news again last year when he announced that he would be taking back the name Mike Penner.

 I think it's sad whenever anyone takes their life. That said, was he a gentle and kind man as the sports editor said above? emoticon_confused
Symbiote

He once wrote
 
 "When you reach the point when one gender causes heartache and unbearable discomfort, and the other brings more joy and fulfillment than you ever imagined possible, it shouldn't take two tons of bricks to fall in order to know what to do."
 
 But it doesn't seem to have worked out that way.
 
 Would he have been happier if he had retained his feminine identity?
 Or adopted it sooner?
 Or never made the change at all?
 Or lived in a repressive society where he could never even consider it?
 
 Who can really say?
 
 I really dislike the use of personal, emotive stories, as typically associated with identity politics; they tend to divide the world into a saintly ingroup and a demonic outgroup, and then foster antagonism between these groups - just wait for someone to show up and telling you this man is now "burning in the pit".
 
 I appreciate the thought, jazyjason, I just don't know how productive it is to personalise political issues (or politicise personal issues) in this way, even if it's effective in converting people to the cause, or stirring up the base of supporters, it seems to lower the level of discourse to a catfight.
 
 I suppose it comes down to whether you consider ethics ultimately to be rational or purely emotional.
